journeys.title: Healing and Restoration After Divorce
journeys.summary: Activities to stabilize your emotions, rebuild peace, and start healing without rushing your process.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: Stabilize Your Day
missions.subtitle: Small stability steps give your heart room to heal.
missions.whyThisMatters: After separation, your emotions can swing quickly. Stability isn’t pretending you’re fine. It’s giving yourself simple anchors so your day doesn’t fall apart.

cards.title: Begin Here
cards.text:
You’re trying to heal without pretending you’re okay can feel like it rewrote your whole story. Today, we take one piece back.

It’s about creating steadiness. When you feel steady, you make better decisions and you heal faster.

cards.title: Choose Your Hardest Time of Day
cards.prompt: When do you feel most vulnerable right now?
options: Early morning when the day starts.
Midday when I’m alone or quiet.
Whenever I see something that reminds me of them.

cards.title: Build Your 3 Anchors
bullets: ANCHOR 1 (BODY): drink water and eat one proper meal today.
ANCHOR 2 (MIND): write one paragraph titled “What I feel today is.”
ANCHOR 3 (ENVIRONMENT): reset one small space (bed, sink, desk, floor).
Choose a time to do each anchor. Put it in your notes.
Finish with: “I can be hurting and still be steady.”

cards.title: Why This Works
cards.text:
When life feels unstable, your brain searches for control. Anchors give your body a signal: “I’m safe enough to breathe.” That’s when clarity returns.

Scripture anchor: Be kind, tenderhearted, forgiving. (Ephesians 4:32) Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, steady me today. Help me take simple steps that protect my peace. Hold me while I heal. Amen.

completionCard.title: You chose support
completionCard.message: You didn’t isolate today. That matters.

missions.title: Create Your Safety Circle
missions.subtitle: You weren’t made to carry this alone.
missions.whyThisMatters: Isolation makes separation pain heavier. Healing becomes easier when you have a few safe people who can help you stay grounded and remind you who you are.

cards.title: Before You Start
cards.text: You don’t need a large crowd. You need a small circle. Right now you’ll identify who is safe, who is neutral, and who drains you.

cards.title: Choose Your Support Mix
cards.prompt: Which support do you need most right now?
options: Someone to listen without fixing me.
Someone who helps me stay practical and stable.
Someone who checks on me when I go quiet.
Someone who can guide me with wisdom.

cards.title: Build Your Safety Circle
bullets: Write 3 names of people who make you feel safe and calm.
Journal 2 names of people you should limit right now (gossip, judgment, drama).
Send one message today to a safe person: “Can you check on me this week?”
Create one boundary: mute, limit updates, or reduce contact with one draining person.
End by writing: “I’m allowed to receive support.”

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text: Some people keep suffering because they want to look strong. But strength is not isolation. Strength is choosing support before you collapse. Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

cards.title: What This Changes
cards.text: The right people won’t shame your grief. They’ll help you stay steady while you rebuild. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

completionCard.title: You protected your peace
completionCard.message: That small change reduced emotional weight.

missions.title: Stop the Mental Replay of the Separation Early
missions.subtitle: Your mind is not trying to torture you. It’s trying to protect you.
missions.whyThisMatters: After separation, many people relive pain through repeated thoughts. The replay feels like problem-solving, but it often keeps you stuck. In this step you will interrupt the replay and discover what it is protecting.

cards.title: First, Breathe
cards.text: If you keep replaying scenes, arguments, and what you should have said, you’re not crazy. You’re trying to get a different ending from the past. Right now you’ll learn how to interrupt the replay and lead yourself back to peace.

cards.title: Choose What Replays Most
cards.prompt: Which replay shows up the most for you?
options: Re-reading messages and searching for meaning.
Replaying moments I ignored red flags.
Rehearsing what I want to say to them.

cards.title: Do This When the Replay Starts
bullets: STEP 1: Name it. Say quietly: This is mental replay.
STEP 2: Ask: What am I trying to get from this replay? (control, closure, justice, reassurance, punishment).
STEP 3: Write: If I stop replaying, I will have to feel ______ (grief, loneliness, shame, fear).
STEP 4: Give your mind a safer job: text your safe person, walk 5 minutes, wash your face, read a Psalm, or journal the emotion you’re avoiding.
Finish with one sentence: I don’t need to replay. I need to feel and release.

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text:
A woman said, “I replayed the separation conversation every night. I thought I was healing. I was actually trying to win in my head because I couldn’t win in real life.”

The breakthrough was one sentence: “I’m replaying because I want justice, but I actually need peace.” Interrupt the replay early and redirect your focus. Peace is your pace. Do not rush ahead of it.

cards.title: Why This Matters
cards.text: Mental replay is your brain trying to regain control. But control is not the same as healing. Healing begins when you stop asking, “How could this happen?” and start asking, “What is this pain trying to teach me?” Interrupt the replay early and redirect your focus. Peace is your pace. Do not rush ahead of it.

completionCard.title: You calmed yourself
completionCard.message: You led your emotions instead of being led.

missions.title: Stop Reopening the Wound
missions.subtitle: You can’t heal what you keep touching.
missions.whyThisMatters: Every time you check, revisit, or re-engage emotionally, you reopen the injury. In this step you will build a boundary that protects your peace without turning you cold.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text: Distance is not bitterness. Distance is medicine. In this moment you’ll stop feeding the wound and give your heart space to breathe.

cards.title: What Reopens It?
cards.prompt: What pulls you back most often?

cards.title: Your 7-day Boundary
bullets: Choose 3 days or 7 days where you will not reopen the wound.
During the window: no checking, no scrolling, no rereading, no updates through friends.
If communication is required, keep it short and factual.
Write: “For the next ___ days, I will not reopen this wound.”
Choose one replacement habit for urges: walk, journal, pray, call someone safe.

cards.title: A Steady Reminder
cards.text:
Curiosity can be pain in disguise. If it costs you peace every time, it is not harmless. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm.

Scripture anchor: Trust God and He will direct your path. (Proverbs 3:5-6) Let the next step be small and specific. Keep your dignity in every small decision.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: God, help me protect my heart. Give me discipline and peace as I heal. Amen.

completionCard.title: You created space
completionCard.message: That space helped your heart breathe.

missions.title: Replace Shame with a Stronger Sentence
missions.subtitle: You will speak to yourself with dignity again.
missions.whyThisMatters: Divorce can turn shame into your inner voice. Shame doesn’t correct you. It humiliates you. you’ll replace one shame line with truth that restores strength.

cards.title: Start with This
cards.text: Shame speaks in labels. Truth speaks in specifics. In this moment you will replace one shame sentence with a steady truth sentence you can stand on.

cards.title: Choose the Shame Sentence
cards.prompt: Which one comes back most often?
options: No one will love me again.

cards.title: Write the Replacement
bullets: Answer the shame sentence exactly as it comes.
Answer a truth sentence: “Even though ______, God is still ______.”
Put on paper it three times, say it once out loud.
Put it somewhere visible for 7 days.
When shame returns, repeat the truth sentence and do one grounding action.

cards.title: One Thing to Remember
cards.text: If the voice inside you crushes you, it is not God’s voice. God restores people with truth and patience. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Speak to yourself like God speaks to you. Let your actions match your values today.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, replace shame with truth. Restore my dignity and remind me who I am in You. Amen.

completionCard.title: You stayed grounded
completionCard.message: One truth can stop a spiral.

missions.title: Cut Off One Trigger Today
missions.subtitle: You are allowed to protect your mind.
missions.whyThisMatters: Some healing doesn’t come from reflection. It comes from removal. cut off one trigger that keeps dragging you back into pain.

cards.title: Begin Here
cards.text: You don’t need to be stronger than your triggers. You need to stop feeding them. In this moment you’ll remove one hook with courage.

cards.title: Choose Your Trigger
cards.prompt: Which trigger hooks you the most?

cards.title: Remove It Today
bullets: Choose one trigger and take one strong action: unfollow, mute, archive, delete, hide, or log out.
Add a safety step: remove shortcuts, clear search history, block if needed.
Answer: “I’m not feeding this wound anymore.”
Replace it with a peace signal: verse, calming photo, or healthy routine.

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text:
Many people keep checking because they want closure. But each check makes them feel smaller. Healing begins when you stop reopening the injury.

If you notice panic, hopelessness, or you cannot function day to day, reach out for support. A trusted pastor, a mature mentor, or a qualified professional can help you carry this wisely. Let the next step be small and specific. Do the next right thing, then rest.

completionCard.title: You reduced triggers
completionCard.message: That choice made healing easier today.

missions.title: Grieve without Collapsing
missions.subtitle: Grief becomes lighter when you name it.
missions.whyThisMatters: Many people skip grief and jump into survival. But grief returns as anger, numbness, or fear. you’ll grieve with structure so you don’t drown.

cards.title: Before You Start
cards.text: You didn’t only lose a person. You lost routines, identity, safety, and future plans. In this moment you’ll name the loss so it doesn’t own you.

cards.title: Choose the Loss
cards.prompt: Which loss hurts most today?

cards.title: Grief with Structure
bullets: Set a 10-minute timer.
Put on paper: What I miss is. What it cost me is. What I need now is ______
When the timer ends, write: “I can carry this and still live.”
Do one grounding action: water, walk, shower, or call a safe person.

cards.title: This Is the Shift
cards.text:
Grief isn’t weakness. It’s the price of loving. Naming grief turns pain into something you can heal. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm.

Scripture anchor: Even in the valley, God is with you. (Psalm 23:4) Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

completionCard.title: You helped your body
completionCard.message: Your body processed stress better today.

missions.title: Forgiveness without Denial
missions.subtitle: Release your grip without rewriting history.
missions.whyThisMatters: Forgiveness is not pretending. It is refusing to stay chained to pain. In this exercise you’ll practice forgiveness in a way that protects you without denying the truth.

cards.title: First, Breathe
cards.text: Forgiveness is a decision you revisit. It means: “This pain will not own me forever.” You’re not here to impress anyone with strength. You’re here to build a life that feels calm again.

cards.title: What Makes Forgiveness Hard?
cards.prompt: Which one is most true for you?
options: I still want them to suffer.
I’m afraid of being hurt again.
I don’t trust God with justice.

cards.title: Do the Release Step
bullets: Write three lines: What happened was. What it cost me was. What I still feel is ______
Write: “God, I release my right to get even. Heal my heart.”
Choose one release action today: stop checking, stop rehearsing arguments, stop updates through friends.

cards.title: A Quick Truth
cards.text: Forgiveness is strength with boundaries. It sets your future free, even if the past was unfair. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Let the next step be small and specific. Peace is your pace. Do not rush ahead of it.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, help me release what I cannot change. Heal my heart and lead me forward. Amen.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.body:
Lord, help me apply what I learned today.
Give me wisdom, peace, and strength.
Let Your Word guide my next steps.
Amen.

completionCard.title: You invited comfort
completionCard.message: Prayer brought you back to peace.

missions.title: Reclaim Your Identity
missions.subtitle: Separation is something that happened. It is not who you are.
missions.whyThisMatters: Divorce can shrink your identity into one label. you will rebuild identity rooted in truth so shame no longer leads you.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text: Your marriage ended. You did not end. Right now you’ll name the lie and replace it with a truth you can live out.

cards.title: Choose the Lie
cards.prompt: Which identity lie shows up most?

cards.title: Replace It with Action
bullets: Complete the lie.
Complete the truth that replaces it.
Write one action that matches the truth and do it today.
Save your truth in your notes and return to it for 7 days.

cards.title: What This Changes
cards.text: Healing is not pretending you are fine. Healing is walking forward with truth, discipline, and dignity. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

missions.title: Build Your New Foundations
missions.subtitle: You’re not starting from zero. You’re starting from wisdom.
missions.whyThisMatters: The goal is not to move on fast. The goal is to build well. you’ll create a foundation plan that protects your next season.

cards.title: Start with This
cards.text: Your future deserves structure, not just hope. Right now you’ll build a simple plan you can return to when emotions rise.

cards.title: Your Foundation Plan
bullets: Put on paper five lines:
The kind of person I am becoming
The habits that keep me steady
The boundaries that protect my peace
The people who support my growth
The faith practice that anchors me
Circle one and pick one action for today.

cards.title: Why This Matters
cards.text:
You don’t need a perfect future. You need a steady one. Small structure builds big peace. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm.

Scripture anchor: God comforts you so you can keep going. (2 Corinthians 1:3-4) Let the next step be small and specific. Peace is your pace. Do not rush ahead of it.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, help me build wisely. Give me peace, discipline, and hope. Let my next season be healthier than my last. Amen.

completionCard.title: Journey complete
completionCard.message: You started healing with steady steps.

journeys.title: Processing Past Relationship Pain
journeys.summary: Activities to process what hurt you, stop emotional bleeding, and regain your peace without denial.

milestones.title: Halfway through
milestones.message: You are becoming stronger and steadier.

missions.title: Name the Pain Clearly
missions.subtitle: Vague pain stays longer. Named pain starts healing.
missions.whyThisMatters: After separation, pain can become one heavy cloud. When it stays vague, it controls you. When you name it clearly, you stop drowning and start healing what’s actually there.

cards.title: Begin Here
cards.text: If you only say “I’m hurt,” your mind will keep searching for answers. Right now you will name the pain with clarity so it stops controlling you in the background.

cards.title: Choose What Hurt Most
cards.prompt: Which pain feels sharpest right now?
options: Betrayal. I trusted them and they broke it.
Rejection. I wasn’t chosen the way I needed.
Humiliation. I feel embarrassed about what happened.
Neglect. I carried too much alone.
Abandonment. They left emotionally or physically.

cards.title: Write It with Precision
bullets: Split a page into three sections.
What happened: write it in two sentences only. Facts, not the full story.
What it cost you: finish the line “This cost me ______.”
What it makes you fear now: finish the line “Now I’m afraid that ______.”
Circle the biggest cost and write: “This is the real wound I’m carrying.”

cards.title: Why This Works
cards.text:
When pain is vague, your mind keeps circling. When pain is named, you can respond to it. Clarity turns suffering into something you can heal.

Scripture anchor: The Lord is close to the brokenhearted. (Psalm 34:18) Let the next step be small and specific. Let consistency prove your healing, not your mood.

completionCard.title: You named it
completionCard.message: Naming pain is a step toward freedom.

missions.title: Stop Self-blame Today
missions.subtitle: Responsibility heals. Self-punishment destroys.
missions.whyThisMatters: Self-blame can look like humility, but it often hides shame. It keeps you stuck in punishment and blocks growth. In this moment you will separate responsibility from self-destruction.

cards.title: Before You Start
cards.text: Ownership helps you grow. Self-punishment keeps you trapped. Right now you will end the punishment without dodging the truth.

cards.title: Be Honest
cards.prompt: When you think about the relationship, where does your mind go?
options: I blame myself even when they were wrong.
I blame myself because it helps me feel in control.
I blame myself because I feel ashamed.
I don’t blame myself, but I still feel heavy guilt.

cards.title: Two Columns
bullets: Draw two columns.
COLUMN 1: What was mine. Write 3 honest responsibilities. No insults, no excuses.
COLUMN 2: What was not mine. Write 3 things you are not responsible for.
Write: “I take responsibility for my part. I release the shame that is not mine.”
Write one commitment: “In my next season, I will ______.”

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text: Self-blame can feel like control because it keeps you focused on what you could have done. But it also keeps you chained to shame. Healing begins when you accept: “I did my part. They did their part. And I can still rebuild.” Let the next step be small and specific. Do the next right thing, then rest.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, help me own what is mine without crushing myself. Free me from shame and teach me to grow with wisdom. Amen.

missions.title: Release One Item
missions.subtitle: Let one object stop having power over you.
missions.whyThisMatters: Some pain stays alive because your hands keep touching it. Right now you will release one item that keeps your heart stuck, without pretending it didn’t matter.

cards.title: First, Breathe
cards.text: This is not about erasing the past. It’s about removing one emotional hook so you can breathe again.

cards.title: Pick the Hardest Item
cards.prompt: What item keeps pulling your heart back?
options: A piece of clothing or scent.
A place in the house that holds the weight.

cards.title: Release It with Honor
bullets: Set a 15 minute timer. You are doing one item only.
Hold the item and name what it represents in one sentence.
Say out loud: “You mattered. But you will not control me.”
Put it in a sealed box or hidden folder. If you’re ready, remove it completely.
Replace it with one peace signal: verse card, calming photo, or symbol of your future.
Journal: “Today I released ______.”

cards.title: A Wiser Lens
cards.text: Your heart learns through your actions. When you release one item, you teach your mind: “I’m safe enough to let go.” For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Say the release sentence once, then move your body. Let consistency prove your healing, not your mood.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: God, help me release what keeps reopening pain. Give me courage to let go with dignity. Amen.

completionCard.title: You loosened the grip
completionCard.message: Letting go creates room for peace.

missions.title: Write What You Learned
missions.subtitle: Turn pain into wisdom without becoming bitter.
missions.whyThisMatters: If you don’t process what happened, you risk repeating it. turn your experience into wisdom that protects your future.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text: This is not about blaming or rewriting history. It’s about learning so you don’t carry the same wound into your next season.

cards.title: Choose Your Focus
cards.prompt: What lesson do you need most right now?
options: I ignored red flags because I wanted love.
I abandoned my needs to keep peace.
I stayed too long hoping it would change.
I tolerated disrespect because I feared being alone.
I lost myself trying to keep the relationship.

cards.title: Write It Clearly
bullets: Finish these three lines:
What I wish I had admitted earlier is ______
The pattern I will never normalize again is ______
The boundary I will keep next time is ______
Write one promise: “In my next season, I will.”
Put that promise somewhere you can see it.

cards.title: This Is the Shift
cards.text:
Wisdom is not pretending you didn’t love. Wisdom is admitting what love blinded you to. Learning doesn’t erase pain, but it turns pain into protection.

Scripture anchor: Come to Jesus when you are weary. (Matthew 11:28-30) Let the next step be small and specific. Clarity beats intensity. Keep it simple.

completionCard.title: You gained wisdom
completionCard.message: Wisdom is the reward of pain when you learn.

missions.title: Time-box Your Sadness
missions.subtitle: Give grief a space so it stops ambushing you.
missions.whyThisMatters: When sadness has no boundaries, it can take over your day. When sadness is honored with structure, it becomes lighter over time. create a safe space for grief.

cards.title: Start with This
cards.text: You’re not trying to stop feeling. You’re choosing when and how you feel, so you don’t drown. You’re not here to impress anyone with strength. You’re here to build a life that feels calm again.

cards.title: Pick a Time
cards.prompt: When can you give sadness a safe space today?

cards.title: Your Grief Container
bullets: Set a timer for 10 minutes.
During the 10 minutes, you are allowed to feel fully. Cry, write, breathe, be honest.
Answer: “What I miss is.” and finish it in one paragraph.
When the timer ends, close with: “I can carry this and still live.”
Do one grounding action: wash your face, drink water, step outside, or play a calm song.
If sadness returns later, tell yourself: “I’ll meet you at your time.”

cards.title: A Quick Truth
cards.text: Grief doesn’t need to be feared. It needs to be held. Structure helps your heart process pain without collapsing. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Let the next step be small and specific. One calm choice today is a victory.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, meet me in my grief. Hold me when it feels heavy. Help me feel without drowning. Amen.

completionCard.title: You held your day
completionCard.message: You felt it without losing your whole day.

missions.title: Release Anger Safely
missions.subtitle: Anger is often grief wearing armor.
missions.whyThisMatters: Anger can protect you from pain, but it can also poison you. release anger in a way that protects your dignity and your future.

cards.title: Begin Here
cards.text: Anger is not always sin. Sometimes it is pain asking to be seen. The goal is not to explode. The goal is to release it safely.

cards.title: What Does Anger Protect?
cards.prompt: What is your anger protecting you from?

cards.title: Do the Release
bullets: Put on paper: “I’m angry because.” and finish it without editing yourself.
Journal: “Under my anger, I feel.” and name the deeper emotion.
Choose one safe release method (10 minutes): fast walk, intense cleaning, journaling, voice note to yourself, or prayer.
Wrap up with: “My anger is real, but it will not lead my life.”
If you need to confront someone, wait 24 hours before you do.

cards.title: A Real Reminder
cards.text:
A woman said, “My anger made me feel strong. But it also kept me tied to him.” When she admitted, “I’m angry because I’m grieving,” the anger softened and she felt free again.

If you notice panic, hopelessness, or you cannot function day to day, reach out for support. A trusted pastor, a mature mentor, or a qualified professional can help you carry this wisely. Say the release sentence once, then move your body. Peace is your pace. Do not rush ahead of it.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: God, help me release anger without hardening my heart. Heal what is underneath it. Teach me to respond with wisdom. Amen.

missions.title: Stop Measuring Yourself Against Them
missions.subtitle: Comparison reopens wounds and steals dignity.
missions.whyThisMatters: After separation, it’s common to compare who moved on faster or who looks happier. Comparison keeps you emotionally attached. In this step you will cut it off and reclaim your dignity.

cards.title: Before You Start
cards.text: Comparison is not information. It is self-harm. It keeps you tied to a life you’re trying to release.

cards.title: Where Do You Compare?
cards.prompt: Where does comparison hit you most?

cards.title: Replace Comparison with a Better Question
bullets: When you notice comparison, pause and ask: “What am I afraid this means about me?”
Complete the answer in one sentence.
Ask: “What do I need to build for myself this month?”
Note down one concrete step you’ll take in the next 7 days.
Mute or unfollow anything that feeds comparison today.

cards.title: Why This Matters
cards.text:
You don’t heal by proving you’re fine. You heal by building a life that is steady. Your story is not a competition.

Scripture anchor: Cast your cares on God because He cares. (1 Peter 5:7) Let the next step be small and specific. Let your actions match your values today.

missions.title: Forgive Yourself for What You Didn’t Know
missions.subtitle: You made choices with the tools you had then.
missions.whyThisMatters: Many people carry private shame about what they tolerated or ignored. That shame keeps you stuck. In this exercise you will forgive yourself without excusing what happened.

cards.title: First, Breathe
cards.text: Self-forgiveness is not pretending you were perfect. It is releasing self-hatred so you can grow. You’re not here to impress anyone with strength. You’re here to build a life that feels calm again.

cards.title: What Do You Judge Yourself For?
cards.prompt: Which one is most true?
options: Trying too hard to make it work.

cards.title: Write Your Self-forgiveness Statement
bullets: Put on paper: “I forgive myself for ______.” Be specific.
Answer: “I didn’t know. I was trying to survive. I was trying to love.”
Put on paper one lesson you learned and one boundary you will keep now.
Place a hand on your chest and say: “I release self-hatred. I choose growth.”

cards.title: A Steady Reminder
cards.text: Shame says, “You should have known.” Wisdom says, “You can learn now.” God restores people with patience and truth. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Let the next step be small and specific. Choose the next step you can repeat, not the perfect step.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: Father, help me forgive myself. Heal the shame I’ve carried. Teach me to grow with humility and strength. Amen.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.body:
Lord, help me apply what I learned today.
Give me wisdom, peace, and strength.
Let Your Word guide my next steps.
Amen.

missions.title: Rebuild Trust Slowly
missions.subtitle: Trust is rebuilt through patterns, not promises.
missions.whyThisMatters: After pain, you can become guarded forever or rebuild trust wisely. In this step you will define what safe trust looks like, so fear doesn’t lead you.

cards.title: Ground Yourself
cards.text: You don’t need to trust quickly. You need to trust wisely. Wisdom helps you stay soft without being naive.

cards.title: Where Trust Feels Hardest
cards.prompt: Where do you struggle to trust most now?
options: Trusting that love can be safe.

cards.title: Define Safe Trust
bullets: Complete 3 signs of safe people for you.
Answer 3 red flags you will no longer ignore.
Answer one rule: “I will not trust words without proof.”
Choose one small trust action: open up to a safe friend, join a group, or ask for prayer.
Finish with: “I can heal and still be wise.”

cards.title: One Thing to Remember
cards.text: Trust is not a switch. It’s a process. The goal is not to become fearless. The goal is to become discerning. For example: when a message comes in that makes your chest tighten, pause, breathe, and reply with facts only. That single decision is how you train your nervous system to stay calm. Do not rush access, let time prove character. One calm choice today is a victory.

cards.title: A Short Prayer
cards.text: God, help me trust again with wisdom. Heal fear, restore discernment, and lead me into safe connection. Amen.
